text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT

- Sweden will get an immoderate advantage in the sawn timber industry if it stays out of the third phase of EMU and the crown depreciates, warns Jukka Harmala, chairman of the Central Union of Agricultural Producers and Forest Owners (MTK).
- Stock issues of the newly listed companies have been immensely popular on Helsinki stock exchange.
- Economy continues to have balanced growth and unemployment will fall to 13 percent next year, finance ministry forecasts.
- Finlandia House will after all be covered with marble plaques, Helsinki city council decided on Monday.
- State broadcaster YLE will start experimenting with digital transmissions already next autumn.
- Investigation of economic crimes should be centralised in a wholly new authority formed by economic crime prosecutors and police, researchers say.
KAUPPALEHTI
- New state budget will continue the line of stringent savings, but no new cuts planned, Prime Minister Lipponen says.
- Multinational brand producer Procter & Gamble annoyed by Finland's campaign for domestic products, saying it harms competition.
- Housing and construction subsidies will be cut to achieve billions of markka savings in tax burden and expenses, working group at finance ministry plans.
- Brokerage Carnegie rumoured to be buying Erik Selin.
- Construction company Onninen plans to become market leader in Lithuania.
AAMULEHTI
- No reason to assume anything will change after French elections, Lipponen says.
- Only a few women lead as executives in Finnish companies.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Regional telephone company Turun Puhelin to be sold to provincial LSP-group formed by local telephone companies, Turku city council decided on Monday.
DEMARI
- Finnish decision makers do not believe French leftist election win will change EMU timetable, but it will raise discussion about the substance of monetary union.
-- Nora Hallberg, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 292
